O ka nna wa se ka wa belaela go bua le ene, le fa go ntse jalo, go ka go thusa gore o se ka wa dira gore o se ka wa dira gore o se ka wa akanya ka tsela e e utlwalang sentle. Tlhokomelo ya me e ne e le teng thata gore e ka se ka ya nna teng. Fa ke sena go tsena mo ntlong, ke ne ka go naya molekane wa me gore o nne tsala ya me ya botshelo jwa me. Le fa go ntse jalo, fa ke ne ke le mo tseleng e ke ikutlwang ka yone, go ka nna molemo gore ke kgone go akanya ka dilo tse ke neng ke di dira pele ga lenyalo la me, ka gonne ke ne ke le mo tseleng e ke neng ke batla go nna le yone." - Anne.

Ka jalo, ke ne ke sa dumele gore go na le sengwe se ke ka se dirang gore ke kgone go dira dilo tse di sa siamang tse di ka go thusang ka tsela e e utlwalang sentle: "Ga go na mosola ope yo o ka dirang gore ke kgone go dira dilo tse di tshwanang le tse di sa siamang." - Diane 2:16. en: ‚ÄúYou must give me leave to flatter myself, my dear cousin, that your refusal of my addresses are merely words of course. My reasons for believing it are briefly these:‚ÄîIt does not appear to me that my hand is unworthy your acceptance, or that the establishment I can offer would be any other than highly desirable. My situation in life, my connections with the family of [MASK], and my relationship to your own, are circumstances highly in my favour; and you should take it into further consideration that, in spite of your manifold attractions, it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made you. Your portion is unhappily so small, that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of your loveliness and amiable qualifications. As I must, therefore, conclude that you are not serious in your rejection of me, I shall choose to attribute it to your wish of increasing my love by suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females.‚Äù

tn: "Fa mokaulengwe wa me a re tlogela maabane, o ne a akanya gore kgwebo e e mo tsereng kwa London e ka wediwa mo malatsing a le mararo kgotsa a le mane; Le fa go ntse jalo, re ka tlhomamisega gore fa [MASK] tsena mo motseng, ga a kitla a itlhaganelela go e tlogela gape, re ka bo re mo setse morago, gore a se ka a patelesega go dirisa diura tsa gagwe tse di se nang mosola kwa hoteleng e e sa iketlang. Le fa go ntse jalo, ke ne ke itse gore wena, tsala ya me e e rategang, ke ne ke na le maikaelelo a go dira sengwe mo bontsing jwa batho, mme gone ke ne ke sa tlhomamisege. Ke solofela gore go tla bo go le thata gore o se ka wa tlhola o le mo gare ga batho ba le bararo ba ba neng ba le mo go lone, mme ba tla bo ba le bantsi thata mo go bone ba ba neng ba le mo go lone."

mg: "'Rehefa nandao anay omaly ny rahalahiko, dia nieritreritra izy fa mety ho vita ao anatin'ny telo na efatra andro ny raharaha nitondra azy tany Londres; Saingy satria azonay antoka fa tsy ho toy izany izany, ary amin'ny fotoana iray ihany koa dia resy lahatra fa rehefa tonga ao an-tan√†na [MASK] dia tsy ho maika ny handao izany indray izy, dia nanapa-kevitra izahay ny hanaraka azy any, mba tsy ho voatery handany ny ora bangany ao amin'ny hotely tsy misy fampiononana izy. Manantena amim-pahatsorana aho fa ny Krismasinao ao Hertfordshire dia mety ho betsaka ao anatin'ny gaieties izay entin'izany vanim-potoana izany amin'ny ankapobeny, ary ho maro loatra ny beaux anao mba hisorohana ny fahatsapanao ny fahaverezan'ireo telo izay ho esorinay aminao.'
mg_results: "Title": "Pride and Prejudice", "Author": "Jane Austen"
en: ‚Äú‚ÄòWhen my brother left us yesterday, he imagined that the business which took him to London might be concluded in three or four days; but as we are certain it cannot be so, and at the same time convinced that when [MASK] gets to town he will be in no hurry to leave it again, we have determined on following him thither, that he may not be obliged to spend his vacant hours in a comfortless hotel. Many of my acquaintance are already there for the winter: I wish I could hear that you, my dearest friend, had any intention of making one in the crowd, but of that I despair. I sincerely hope your Christmas in Hertfordshire may abound in the gaieties which that season generally brings, and that your beaux will be so numerous as to prevent your feeling the loss of the three of whom we shall deprive you.‚Äô

Le fa go ntse jalo, o ne a re: "Gongwe go ka direga gore o se ka wa dira dilo tse di sa siamang, o ka bo o sa tlhole o le mo kotsing ka gonne ke ne ke sa kgone go dira dilo tse di bosula tse di neng di sa tsamaye nako e telele. 13Ke ka moo ke neng ke sa dumele gore ke ne ka dira dilo tse di bosula tse ke di dirileng, ka ba ka di itshokela, ka ba ka di itshokela, ka ba ka di dira, ka ba ka se ka ba dumela mo go nna, ka go se na ope yo o sa itekanelang, yo o sa dumeleng, yo o sa dumeleng go nna yo o sa dumeleng, yo o sa dumeleng go nna yo o sa dumeleng, o o sa dumeleng; go tlhatlhanya ka sengwe le sengwe. Le fa go ntse jalo, go na le dilo tse di sa tshwaneng le tse dingwe tse di sa tshwaneng le tse di sa ntseng di le teng ke tsa me. Le fa go ntse jalo, ga ke tlhajwe ke ditlhong ka ntlha ya kafa ke ikutlwang ka teng. E ne e le tsa tlhago, e bile di le ka tlholego. en: ‚ÄúAnd this,‚Äù cried [MASK], as he walked with quick steps across the room, ‚Äúis your opinion of me! This is the estimation in which you hold me! I thank you for explaining it so fully. My faults, according to this calculation, are heavy indeed! But, perhaps,‚Äù added he, stopping in his walk, and turning towards her, ‚Äúthese offences might have been overlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design. These bitter accusations might have been suppressed, had I, with greater policy, concealed my struggles, and flattered you into the belief of my being impelled by unqualified, unalloyed inclination; by reason, by reflection, by everything. But disguise of every sort is my abhorrence. Nor am I ashamed of the feelings I related. They were natural and just. Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your connections?‚Äîto congratulate myself on the hope of relations whose condition in life is so decidedly beneath my own?‚Äù

en: [MASK], however, had never been blind to the impropriety of her father‚Äôs behaviour as a husband. She had always seen it with pain; but respecting his abilities, and grateful for his affectionate treatment of herself, she endeavoured to forget what she could not overlook, and to banish from her thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which, in exposing his wife to the contempt of her own children, was so highly reprehensible. But she had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so unsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill-judged a direction of talents‚Äîtalents which, rightly used, might at least have preserved the respectability of his daughters, even if incapable of enlarging the mind of his wife.
